story: :root How hot does your town like it  The nations spice preferences revealed... Are you a heat-loving West Midlander  Or perhaps a more chilli-wary east of England resident  Our survey reveals which areas in the UK are partial to a bit of spiceAbstract luxury soft Red background Christmas Valentines layout design,studio,room, web template ,Business report with smooth circle gradient colorAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep  We all know that KFC ’s Popcorn Chicken is practically a national treasure – crunchy, moreish, delicious little pops of  per cent chicken breast – but here’s some news: IT JUST GOT SPICY. For a limited time, it’s acquired an edge, a kick, a fiery twist to tantalise your tastebuds. Introducing the Zinger Popcorn Bucket.Trialled in ten lucky locations in April, it proved so popular it’s now officially launching across the UK, so that everyone can feel the burn! But where are the spice fiends who’ll be going straight off to order it, and which of us Brits are more chary with the chilli  SPICE UP YOUR LIFE KFC surveyed the nation’s spice preferences, asking residents in Northern Ireland, Wales, Scotland, London, the North East, North West, Yorkshire, East Midlands, West Midlands, East of England, South East and South West how spicy they like their food. The results show that it’s Londoners who have the biggest appetite for heat:  per cent of those in the capital said they like their food to be nice and spicy or even to feel their mouths on fire. The Scots and West Midlanders are runners-up in their love of the burn, at  and  per cent respectively. But spice is off the menu in Yorkshire: around one in five people declared that they prefer their food mild – the highest number of any region surveyed. Hot on their heelswere those in the East of England. The survey also revealed the gap between people’s estimation of their own region’s appetite for spice and the reality. Residents of Northern Ireland were widest off the mark, guessing that only  per cent would like fiery food, whereas the true figure was  per cent. In contrast,  per cent of those in the North West thought their population would love serious spice, but it was actually a mere  per cent. London and the West Midlands came out top when people were asked which region they thought would have the greatest penchant for spicy food, and they were broadly right. But those in the South West were wrongly assumed to have the least tolerance for the tingle factor. And what about you  Can you take the heat  If you’re a dance-till-dawn, touch-of-the-hedonist kind of person who loves food that makes your eyes widen and your tongue take notice, the Zinger Popcorn Bucket is your order of dreams. If you get your kicks from breaking in your new lambswool slippers in front of Call the Midwe, and your flavour frisson comes from a sprinkling of parsley... maybe not so much. The Zinger Popcorn Bucket is only here until October , so now’s the time to find outyou can handle the heat!Download the app, head in store or order online. title: iceland boss announces staff boxing
story: :root Iceland boss announces all staff will get Boxing Day off and warns of supply shortagesAfter an audience member, also a retail manager, asked about time off over the festive period Icelands Richard Walker confirmed he was planning on giving staff the day offThe exchange took place on BBC Question Time on Thursday Image: BBCByWilliam WalkerNews Reporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe boss of supermarket retailer Iceland has let slip that the company will be giving its staff a day off for Boxing Day this year. Richard Walker appeared on BBCaposs Question Time on Thursday night when he answered a question about the dficulties the industry is facing. After an audience member, also a retail manager, asked about time off over the festive period he confirmed the food retailer was planning on giving its staff the day off. He admitted he was revealing the news a week ahead of a formal company announcement. During the exchange a member of the public said: We have been talking a lot about the delivery issues, Iaposm a store manager in retail and have been for a number of years and itaposs incredibly dficult at the moment.  Last Christmas was really challenging with the lockdowns, everything closing. This year already we are facing dficulties getting products on the shelves. Isnapost it about time that for all retailers to allow their teams to have time off on Boxing Day for the first time  I just think that really should just be a thing for all retailers. I know some big names have already announced it. Surely you guys on the  can do something about that to allow us to spend time with our friends, and our family, after working such an intense period through Christmas. There was a large round of applause from the audience after the question. Answering him Iceland managing director Richard Walker let slip an announcement was set to be made next week about allowing time off.  He said: You havenapost had the option to work from home, unlike most industries, and youaposre right, itaposs a very tough job that is getting tougher. Asked by Fiona Brucehe would like to see the member of the public get Boxing Day off he answered aposyes.apos Before moving to the next question he added: Iaposve just scuppered an announcement for next week I think. He went on to confirm that the company was planning on allowing the day off, prompting another round of applause. It comes after Mr Walker warned that food could run low in supermarkets long before Christmas in a stark warning. He said earlier that food shortages could happen in just weeks. He said: This is no longer about whether or not Christmas will be OK, itaposs about keeping the wheels turning and the lights on so we can actually get to Christmas. This could become a problem over the coming days and weeks, so this is not an issue thataposs months away. He added that Iceland was stocking up on items such as frozen meat, which is already at risk of running low. He added: I think there will be problems before Christmas. No one has a problem just at the moment but it could become a problem over the coming days and weeks. It is not an issue that is months away. Other supermarkets have already announced closures for Boxing Day. Morrisons was the first supermarket to confirm its stores will be shut on Boxing Day this year. Sainsburyaposs also said it would be shut. Aldi will shut all its  shops on Boxing Day, as it has done in previous years, as will Home Bargains. Marks and Spencer also announced it would be shut, giving , staffers the day off. Raducanu to congratulate her on her stunning US Open win - and got competitive by going up against her on court.The -year-old met with Kate Middleton at the Lawn Tennis Associationaposs National Tennis Centre in London, where they teamed up for a doubles game before going head-to-head against each other.And it was even remarked that it was getting competitive.Kate came dressed for the occasion in a navy tennis skirt and tracksuit top and also brought her racket along with her. As well as meeting Emma, Kate also chatted with fellow British US Open champions Joe Salisbury, who won the menaposs doubles title with American Rajeev Ram, and Gordon Reid and Alfie Hewett, the menaposs wheelchair doubles champions. There was an awkward moment when Kate first arrived as she was unsure how to congratulate the group.She said: Are we shaking hands  I donapost want to break your training bubbles.Itaposs really awkward, you donapost know quite whether to do it. It is the same with face masks.You never know whether to hug people, congratulate them or shake hands. But amazing, guys honestly, congratulations.Emma, who is now ranked nd in the world, became the first qualier to win one of the four majors when she claimed the US Open womenaposs singles title earlier this month. She also became the first British woman in  years to win a Grand Slam title, when she breezed past Canadian Leylah Fernandez in straight sets.After her victory, Kate took to Twitter to send a rare personal tweet saying : Huge congratulations @EmmaRaducanu on your stunning performances and historic Grand Slam victory! CThe Queen also said it was a remarkable achievement at such a young age and added she was an inspiration for future tennis players. In a personal message to Emma, she said: I send my congratulations to you on your success in winning the United States Open Tennis Championships. I have no doubt your outstanding performance, and that of your opponent Leylah Fernandez, will inspire the next generation of tennis players. Raducanu shot into the spotlight with a surprise y run to the second week of Wimbledon - her Grand Slam debut tournament earlier this summer. And even before the tournament, it appears that Kate and husband Prince William were fans of the young Brit. title: most common symptom tell difference
story: :root Most common symptom to tell the dference between Covid and a coldSymptoms of the Covid- virus are extremely similar to those of a regular cold, particularly for those who have been double jabbed.A crossover of symptoms makes it dficult to tell the dference between a cold and Covid- Image: Getty ImagesBySophie LawAdvance Content Writer:,  Sep | commentsIn a bid to help people distinguish between coronavirus and a common cold, scientists have revealed the ‘one’ symptom that sets the two apart. Experts have warned of a crossover of symptoms for the past  months, making it dficult to tell the dference between the two illnesses. Symptoms of the virus are extremely similar to those of a regular cold, particularly for those who have been double jabbed.Vaccinated people who contract the virus are likely to experience a runny nose, sore throat and sneezing, the Daily Record reported. But now, new research from the ZOE Covid Symptom study, developed by Kingaposs College London, has found that thereaposs one symptom that can help tell the dference.Data shows that loss of smellor loss of taste is still one of the most important predictors of testing positive for coronavirus rather than a regular cold.Researchers say you can check your sense of smell easily at home by snfing scented foods or products, or noticing whether familiar foods start to lose their flavour or taste strange. Millions of people have been logging their symptoms, tests and vaccines on the UK ZOE COVID Symptom Study app since it was launched. Thanks to health reports, scientists now know there are more than  symptoms of Covid-, including headache, runny nose, sneezing and sore throat. Common Covid symptoms in people fully vaccinated Data as of September : Runny nose Headache Sneezing Sore throat Loss of smellCommon COVID- symptomsyou’re unvaccinated Headache Runny Nose Sore Throat Fever Persistent cough Loss of smellcomes further down the list for unvaccinated people, but it’s still an important predictor of having COVID- rather than a regular cold. title: outsiders must wonder what happened
story: :root Outsiders must wonder what happened to UKs reputation of order and efficiencyThe Voice of the Mirror has questioned what has happened to Britains reputation under Boris Johnson, slamming the governments "incompetence and complacency"Motorists queue for petrol at Sainsburys at Monks Cross, York as drivers are being urged by the Government to buy fuel as normal, after the lorry driver shortage hit supplies Image: Peter HarbouropinionByVoice of the Mirror:,  Sep | commentsAny outsider looking at Britain must wonder what happened to our reputation for being a nation of order and efficiency. A well-run country would not have queues at the fuel pumps, empty shelves in supermarkets and firms unable to source basic goods. Thanks to this Government’s incompetence and complacency, firms have been walloped by rising energy bills, a shortage of CO and a transportation crisis. And that is before you add in the disruption from Covid and economic pain caused by rising living costs. Boris Johnson has been in denial about the chaos caused by these multiple crises. An emergency is looming, but there has been no emergency planning. The Prime Minister likes to boast about Global Britain – but on his watch, we are in danger of becoming Broken Britain. Keir moment  Next week Keir Starmer will finally address the Labour conference in person. The pandemic has been doubly frustrating for the Labour leader, dominating the news, making it harder for the Opposition to be heard and preventing Sir Keir from properly introducing himself to the public. This why so much is riding on his leader’s speech this Wednesday. Sir Keir inherited a broken and ided party which had suffered its fourth election defeat in a row. Since then he has made steady,slow, progress in turning around Labour’s fortunes. The party is in a better place than it was two years ago, but Labour’s rehabilitation is not yet complete. That work must continue at the conference in Brighton. It is time the party stopped talking to itself and began a conversation about how Labour can transform lives and build a better Britain. He was shaken and stirred by nerves, but she delivered a Royal Command Performance. title: perfectly preserved art deco house
story: :root Inside treasure trove house frozen in time since s as it goes on sale for £.mThe Grade II listed home in south London is on the market for £.m and comes with a treasure trove for period furniture loversThe colourful abode is one of just a handful of homes designed by s design duo Kemp  Taske Image: HamptonsByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA perfectly preserved Art Deco house that hasn’t changed since the s has come on the market for the first time since . The property on Dorchester Drive, Herne Hill in south London, has an asking price of £.m and comes with original aposs radiators, original Crittall windows and an original kitchen. The home is just one of handful designed by the design duo Kemp  Tasker, who are perhaps best known for their cinemas. Boasting three receptions rooms, two toilets and five bedrooms, the house also has a large garden, iron staircase, “sunspan” curved windows in the living room, roof terrace, original hardwood flooring, and aposs tiled bathroom.The sellers Hamptons have suggested that the two reception rooms could be knocked into one to create a ft “ballroom”.In  a Kemp  Tasker house design won the Daily Mailaposs Ideal House Competition and was erected temporarily at Olympia in the Village of Tomorrow at Ideal Home Show the following year. The builders, Bromley-based Messrs Morrell Bros. Builders advertised that the home could be built to order anywhere but only three known examples exist - in Dublin, Hayes in Kent and this one on the market. A spokesperson for Hamptons said: Owned by the same family since , this house now provides the opportunity for a buyer to breathe new le into a well-loved family home to create something really special in terms of style and space. It has wonderful features such as curved doors, original hardwood flooring , original Crittall windows, the fabulous apossunspanapos curved window in the lounge, grand iron staircase and original tiled bathroom. There is a wraparound garden and off-street parking on both sides. The original sales brochure described the ground floor as having the option of combining the two reception rooms with the hall to create a forty ft ballroom. Its beautul wooden floor, believed to be maple, also extends into the study which has full- window views over the garden. The roof is a perfect spot to enjoy the sun and the views over London. There is an additional room on the roof, not shown on the floor plan, housing the water tank and providing useful extra storage space. news uk-news petrol-stations-closed-and-fuel-"BP announce petrol station forecourt closures in statementByAriane Sohrabi-ShirazSEO Editor:,  Sep | comments A national fuel shortage is causing petrol stations across the country to close, risking widespread disruption. The UK has been plagued by a number of shortages in recent weeks, brought on by a shortage of HGV drivers.BPaposs head of UK retail Hanna Hofer has said it is important the government understands the urgency of the situation, which she described as bad, very bad, ITV News reports.She added that BP had two-thirds of normal forecourt stock levels required for smooth operations and the level is declining rapidly. Here we take a look at which oil companies have faced petrol station closures, and the reason for the fuel shortage. Which petrol stations have closed   BP and Tesco have closed some petrol stations because of petrol and diesel supply issues, brought on by the lack of HGV drivers. There are around , BPO branded filling stations around the country, of which  are operated by BP themselves, and the oil giant has said a handful of these have been forced to close. The oil giant, which is the largest operator of petrol stations in the UK, has not said which specic ones have closed.  The Mirror reached out to BP, but the company could not confirm which specic petrol stations were closed due to the fast-changing situation. BP said in a statement: “We are experiencing some fuel supply issues at some of our retail sites in the UK and unfortunately have therefore seen a handful of sites temporarily close due to a lack of both unleaded and diesel grades. These have been caused by some delays in the supply chain which has been impacted by the industry-wide driver shortages across the UK and there are many actions being taken to address the issue. We continue to work with our haulier supplier to minimise any future disruption and to ensure efficient and effective deliveries to serve our customers.  They are currently working to address the problem, and prioritising deliveries to motorway service areas, major trunk roads and sites with the largest demands. The company said: We continue to work with our haulier supplier to minimise disruption and to ensure efficient and effective deliveries. Esso, which owns  Tesco Alliance sites, has reported similar issues with a small number of them. A spokesperson said: We are working closely with all parties in our distribution network to optimise supplies and minimise any inconvenience to customers. “We apologise to our customers for any inconvenience.” Currently these are the only two suppliers reporting shortages. Supermarket Morrisons has said itaposs not seeing similar issues with any of its  petrol stations, according to the BBC. Similarly, Co-Op, which operates  petrol stations, has a full complement of fuel delivery drivers. Tesco says it has a good availability of fuel, and the BBC report that both Sainsburyaposs and Asda have had no issues in fuel supplies. Why is there a fuel shortage   Is panic-buying understandable - or selfish  Let us know in the comments below Similarly to the food shortage which is causing empty supermarket shelves, the reason for the fuel shortage is to do disruption to the supply chain. This is due to a post-Brexit shortage in the number of HGV drivers. Since the UK left the European Union, many non-UK nationals who drive trucks have opted to work solely within EU countries. This has left logistics firms struggling to find workers. news uk-news petrol-stations-run-dry-drivers-"Cars queue up at petrol station in Bristol amid fuel crisisByTalia ShadwellReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsMassive queues are forming and tensions are flaring at petrol stations this morning as drivers flock for fuel despite pleas not to panic buy. Some UK service stations are rationing fuel as the lorry driver shortage hits petrol supply chains and forces forecourts up and down the country to shut. Worried drivers formed lines before the break of dawn in hopes of filling up, as scenes queuing stretched into a second day. Others were seen carrying jerry cans onto forecourts.At least one bust-up as been witnessed, as a clash broke out at a busy petrol station in Portsmouth, Hants, where drivers had flocked to a Shell station. Two groups of men were aposscreamingapos at each other before one group chased another fleeing in a van - hurling stones at the vehicle, according to a witness. The ugly scenes shocked onlookers at a forecourt in the Hilsea area of the city at around .am. A witness said: People were queuing throughout the night. Pumps are almost dry.Have you been affected by the shortage  Email your stories and pictures to webnews@mirror The man said the groups were screaming and shouting at each other. He added: One group got into their van and drove off out of the city as the other group gave chase and hurled stones at the retreating van. Itaposs utter madness. Lengthy queues were being spotted today around London, Essex and Kent to Bristol and Cambridgeshire, as industry bosses warned the capital and south of England were worst affected. Some petrol stations had road cones blocking forecourt lanes and signs announcing they were closed as pumps ran dry. Police forces are pleading with drivers to be apossensibleapos as lines were seen stretching around roundabouts in some parts of England. EG Group, which runs hundreds of forecourts across Britain, imposed a purchase limit of £ per customer for fuel due to the unprecedented customer demandaposapos.  Petrol retailers say they are unable to transport fuel due to a lack of lorry drivers, which is being blamed on Brexit labour shortages and the pandemic. Some firms have offered handsome cash incentives, salary increases and free training in desperate bids to recruit and retain drivers, as the exodus of EU workers left firms struggling to fill the gap. Reports have speculated the government is likely to bow shortly to industry demand to issue temporary migrant visas to plug the gaps.  Haulage industry bosses have warned the UK is short nearly , lorry drivers. The problem is being exacerbated by a gas price hike crisis threatening the UKaposs food supplies and driving up energy bills to eye-watering rates. Lincolnshire Police warned the queues could cause chaos on the roads and urged drivers not to fill upthey donapost need to. The force said: This is a potential hazard for vehicles making other journeys, and may cause dficulties for emergency services trying to reach people in need. While we appreciate that some people may be particularly keen to fill up their vehicles this weekend, we would respectfully ask motorists to be sensible when making judgements about joining a queue at a petrol station. If it is too long, consider ing at a dferent time. The president of the AA says panic-buying rather than supply chain issues is driving the shortage of fuel at some petrol stations.  Edmund King said the problem should pass in a matter of daysdrivers just stick to filling up when they need it, adding there is plenty of fuel at source. Speaking to BBC Breakfast, Mr King said shortage of lorry drivers had only been a localised problem earlier in the week. We were in discussions with Government ministers last night and we talked to the major fuel companies, and we can reiterate there is not a problem with supply at the source, Mr King said. Earlier in the week, there were some problems with the supply chain, as we know, due to a shortage of some lorry drivers, but that was only a localised problem.  Mr King warned the shortage had been exacerbated by people going out and filling up when they really donapost need to. If you think about it,  million cars out there,theyaposve all got half a tank they all rush out to fill up the rest of the tank and the tank is about  litres, that will put a strain on the system, he said. Mr King said the issues were unlikely to last because the supply chain is not being disrupted by ongoing problems such as industrial action. The good news is you can only really fill up once - youaposve got to use the fuel, so this should be a short-term thing, he said.  Itaposs not like the fuel crises in the past when the supplier was hit by strikes, etc. So, once people have filled up, they wonapost travel more than they normally travel, so this strain on the system should ease up in the next few days. However Mr King said the lorry driver shortage would remain an ongoing issue for the industry until solutions were found. Andrew Opie, director of food and sustainability at the British Retail Consortium, said: “HGV drivers are the glue which hold our supply chains together. “Without them, we are unable to move goods from farms to warehouses to shops. “Currently, the UK faces a shortfall of around , HGV drivers and it is consumers who ultimately suffer the consequences.” Comment MORE ON Panic-buyingVehiclesBPOn Instagram" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: :root Prince Andrew finally concedes proper service of legal papers in sexual assault lawsuitPrince Andrew is accused of forcing Virginia Gufre to have sex with him at several locations, including properties owned by late financier Jeffrey Epstein when she was a teenagerPrince Andrew has conceded proper service in the United States of a sexual assault lawsuit Image: REUTERSByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Sep Prince Andrew has finally conceded proper service in the United States of a sexual assault lawsuit by accuser Virginia Gufre. The Duke of York is accused of having sex with her on three occasions when she was , knowing she had been trafficked by his close friend, the convicted paedophile Jeffrey Epstein. Andrew and his accuser, now , jointly agreed that service was effective as of September , according to a Friday filing with the US District Court in Manhattan. The prince has until October  to respond to the lawsuit. He denies Giuffreaposs claims. A previously scheduled October  court hearing has been canceled.Do you enjoy reading about the royal family for all the best royal news from the Mirror here  The agreement appears for now to end a monthlong effort by Andrewaposs legal team, including lawyers in Britain, to block Giuffreaposs lawsuit at the outset rather than have the -year-old defend against it. Giuffre accused Queen Elizabethaposs second son of forcing her to have sex around two decades ago at the London home of Epsteinaposs longtime associate Ghislaine Maxwell. She also said Andrew abused her at around the same time at Epsteinaposs mansion in Manhattan and on Epsteinaposs private island in the U.S. Virgin Islands.  Andrew has not been charged with crimes. His lawyers are seeking to review a  settlement agreement from a lawsuit against Epstein in Florida, to determine whether it requires a dismissal of Giuffreaposs August  lawsuit. Giuffre is seeking unspecied damages. Epstein, a registered sex offender, also had a home in Florida. He killed himself in a Manhattan jail in August  while awaiting trial on sex trafficking charges. Giuffre sued Andrew under a  New York law that gave survivors of childhood sexual abuse a since-closed two-year window to sue their alleged abusers over conduct occurring many years or decades earlier. title: proof kate middleton sportiest royal
story: :root Proof Kate Middleton is sportiest royal ever - and which games she thrashes William atAfter Kate Middleton has a go at abseiling and mountain biking during an action-packed visit to the Lake District, we look back at her seriously sporty historyThe daring duchess is up for any challenge Image: Daily Mirror Andy StenningByAlex BellottiNews Features Writer:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsWeaposve seen the Queen at the races and Prince William watching his beloved Aston Villa, but is there any royal more sporty than the Duchess of Cambridge  Over the years, Kate has tried her hand at almost as many sports as there are at the Olympics, proving sheaposs capable at everything from sailing to cricket and even table tennis.This week, the -year-old decided it was time to have a go at abseiling and mountain biking during an action-packed visit to the Lake District.Kate was photographed taking the plunge at Cathedral Quarry in Little Langdale, Cumbria, after going biking with a group of Air Cadets.The sporty streak appears to stretch way back to her teenage years, with school pal Gemma Williamson telling the Daily Mail that “every boy in school fancied her rotten after she impressed them with her talent at hockey and cross-country running.Here, we take a look at the duchessapos finest sporting moments - and how the competitive royal stacks up against her husband Wills. Sailing Kate has a deep love of sailing and showed off her skills in  at the King’s Cup regatta off the Isle of Wight - although she was beaten to the finish line by William. Itaposs no surprise that sheaposs also struck up a friendship with Olympics sailing hero Sir Ben Ainslie, whoaposs even taken her out on the water. Get the biggest news delivered to your inbox.for the Mirroraposs free newslettersThis summer, the Cambridges are said to have made the most of the fleeting sunshine by taking a boat around the Norfolk coast.A local source told Vanity Fairaposs Katie Nicholl that they are very much a family of sailors now after getting the kids up to speed while staying at their holiday home Anmer Hall in early August.“Kate has always been a competent sailor and William’s pretty good too, said the source. Volleyball Donning a pair of five-inch wedges, perhaps Kate was looking for a height advantage when she tried her hand at volleyball. In her first solo engagement since the birth of Prince George, the royal joined young athletes and their parents in education workshops for her charity SportsAid in  - but wasnapost quite dressed for the part in her skinny jeans. The Russell and Bromley heels didnapost stop her at the volleyball net but she did tell one young fencer: Iaposd like to give it a go but Iaposve brought the wrong shoes. She chatted to aspiring athletes and watched them play badminton, volleyball, fencing and wheelchair basketball before posing for a photo with the group. Kate was joined at Londonaposs Olympic Park Copper Box by rower Katherine Grainger and wheelchair basketball player Ade Adepitan as they tutored the next generation of Britainaposs athletes. Hockey Hockey is one of Kateaposs first sporting loves. Sheaposs very good too, having captained her team as a schoolgirl at Marlborough College. Back in , the duchess swapped her skirt suit and heels for a tracksuit top and trainers to join Great Britain’s women’s Olympic hockey team.  And she even grabbed a hockey stick and joined in the practice session herself during her visit to the London  Olympic Park. The dressed-down royal ditched her trademark LK Bennett heels for comfortable trainers as she ran around the pitch at the Riverside Arena in bright coloured skinny jeans .The Duchess’s visit boosted the team, and some took to Twitter to share their excitement.England and GB hockey player Kate Walsh wrote: “A real pleasure and an honour to meet and play hockey with HRH the Duchess of Cambridge this morning!  “Think our team have got Royal approval!” Hannah Macleod praised Kate’s sporting skills, adding: “A pleasure and an honour to meet HRH the Duchess of Cambridge this morning at the Olympic Park. “Sheaposs quite handy at hockey too!” Table tennis As a spectator, Kate can often be spotted in the royal box at Wimbledon watching stars like Andy Murray. A patron of the Lawn Tennis Association, sheaposs also partial to the slightly less sophisticated game of ping pong too.  After sister Pippa boasted about her familyaposs skills back in , the duchess displayed the ‘Middleton competitiveness’ when she took on William during their Scotland visit. Onlookers agreed mum-to-be Kate was the better player as the royal couple had a knockabout at the Donald Dewar leisure centre in the Drumchapel area of the city. The pair were joined in a doubles match by teenagers Yaser Razouk and Stephen Grimes.  Both boys, members of the Drumchapel Table Tennis Club, agreed that Kate won in her match against William. Yaser said he thought they would make a really good doubles team. He said: We knew before they came that we were going to give them the bats, but I never thought weaposd end up playing with them. When they were playing each other at singles William was convinced he was winning but I think it was Kate who ended up the winner. Her knack for table tennis appears to extend into the full court game too.Speaking to the Daily Mail, Australian former world number one Rod Laver said: I’d met William and Kate a few times, and in the Royal Box you get a chance to chat with them a little bit.They play tennis against each other. William told me he couldn’t beat her. Rowing The sight of Kate at the helm of a Dragon Boat on the River Thames is one of the defining images of her love story with Prince William. The royal made her now infamous appearance in the boat in  following a brief split from William as the The Sisterhood rowing team prepared for a cross-Channel race in the traditional Chinese vessel against all-boys crew the Brotherhood. The challenge drew throngs of attention from round the world and, though Kate eventually pulled out over security fears, her team went on to complete the gruelling race. The images were so renowned they even made their way into Hollywood’s William and Kate film, which came out shortly before the couple wed. High jump Like that one annoyingly brilliant friend we all know, Kate has proved herself to be a dab hand at nearly every sport over the ears. Sheaposs had a go at cricket, football tennis and even given archery hurdles a go. Perhaps one of the lesser known facts about the accomplished sportwoman, though, is that she still holds a school record in one field. A talented high jumper, Kate set the still-standing record of . metres when she was a pupil at St Andrewaposs School in Pangbourne, Berkshire, which she attended from  to . Lady Louise Alice Elizabeth Mountbatten-Windsor, , is the daughter of Prince Edward and Sophie, the Countess of Wessex.This week she stepped into the spotlight to commemorate her grandfather Prince Philip in a BBC documentary. Among those who paid tribute was Lady Louise, who recalled her close bond with Prince Philip and their shared love for carriage driving. She is the th in line to the throne and is the grandchild of the Queen, , and her late husband Philip. When her parents Prince Edward and Sophie Rhys-Jones got married in , Buckingham Palace announced their children would not be styled as prince or princess. Instead Louise and her brother James, Viscount Severn, are titled as children of an earl. The decision was said to be part of Edward and Sophieaposs hopes for their children to have as normal a childhood as possible.  Thereports that the final decision on whether to take the title of princess will be left up to Louise when she turns . She will choose whether or not to style herself Her Royal Highness Princess Louise after her birthday with her parents, the Earl and Countess of Wessex, said to be leaving the decision up to their daughter. If she decides to take the new title, she will be styled as Her Royal Highness Princess Louise. The Queenaposs other grandchildren have a mixture of titles with Louiseaposs cousins Princess Beatrice and Eugenie also styling themselves as HRH. Princess Anneaposs children Zara Tindall and Peter Phillips have never held HRH status.  Due to the the  Letters Patent HRH titles could only be passed onto the children of the sovereign, the children of the sovereign’s sons, and the eldest living son of the eldest son of the Prince of Wales. This was amended in  to include all the children of the eldest son of the Prince of Wales. As a result all of the Duke of Cambridgeaposs children have HRH status. Royal expert, Phil Dampier, said that as she comes of age Louise could prove to be the monarchyaposs apossecret weapon.apos He said: Because she’s the granddaughter of the Queen, Lady Louise can call herself a princess when she becomes ... and there’s a strong argument for her doing it.  “She seems to be very mature for her age, and she’s shaping up to be precisely the kind of person the Queen can rely on in the future. “Could there be a role for her in a slimmed-down monarchy  The Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh had , patronages between them. You have to ask yourself who is going to continue their legacy, what with Harry and Meghan and Prince Andrew off the scene  There’s a huge workload there.”Meanwhile, there have been several reports that Lady Louise is the Queenaposs favourite grandchild due to their special bond.A royal source previously told The Sun: The Queen loves the fact that Louise and James relish their time at Balmoral, and she has become particularly close to Louise, who seems to have become her favourite grandchild, closely followed by James. The source added: “Louise also endeared herself to everyone by looking after William and Kate’s children when they were up here. “Louise loves drawing and sketching and was very patiently trying to get Charlotte to do pictures of rabbits and deer. Because of her obvious artistic skill, the Queen allowed Louise to look through some of the collection of Queen Victoria’s Highlands sketches which are kept at Balmoral but are rarely dug out these days.” While the spotlight mainly focuses on Princes William and Harry, the Queen has eight grandchildren, and she is said to be close with them all. story: :root Rats invading homes through toilets as one shocked woman finds pest in bathroomAndrew Dellbridge, head of Ace Pest Control, has seen rats as big as cats in Norwich with rodents becoming bigger and braver, forcing one couple in the city to leave their homeHuge rats are climbing up toilets in Norwich, leaving residents with a nasty shockImage: Getty Images iStockphotoByMatthew DreschReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsRats are invading homes through toilets, with one woman left in shock after spotting a rodent below her when she was using the bathroom. Andrew Dellbridge, head of Ace Pest Control, said rats in Norwich are getting aposbigger and braverapos, forcing one couple in the city to leave their home. He said another customer was left speechless when she used her bathroom, heard a noise and then saw a rat in the toilet bowl below her. Mr Dellbridge said the terrying episode is becoming increasingly common and he has spotted rats aposas big as catsapos in the city. He told the Norwich Evening News: I was called out to one job in Norwich and the customer could barely speak, she was in so much shock. Sheaposd been using the bathroom and heard a noise. She looked down and it was in the toilet bowl. And this is happening more and more frequently. They used to work around us but now theyaposre gaining access they wouldnapost have attempted before. Mr Dellbridge added that the issue is becoming worse due to overflowing bins and wild verges being filled with rubbish. The pest control boss has been working flat-out through the summer, despite the winter usually being his busiest time of the year. He said cats are no longer a solution to a vermin problem as aposa sensible cat doesnapost like a big ratapos. It comes after huge rats ran riot in lockdown Britain - with easy access to food meaning the vermin grew in size and number.  Footage showed a pair of them - the size of a small cat - stealing food from hungry birds. The plump animals climbed up the frame before gorging themselves on the food. The large rodents were scampering around in broad daylight in full view of a family in Accrington, Lancs. Experts said the easy access to food - with many businesses closed during the pandemic - caused the UKaposs rat population to skyrocket. The number of rats increased from  million to  million during , according to pest control company pest.  The big freeze, lockdowns and food stockpiling created the ideal environment for rats and mice to enjoy a little quiet time in vacant buildings. A rataposs bite is in fact six times stronger, relative to their size, than a great white shark, pest expert Jenny Rathbone said. Pest controllers have seen evidence of cunning rats moving a crisp packet and placing it over a glue trap, to enable them to travel across it without being caught. Primary school teacher Sabina, , from Kidbrooke, Greenwich in London, was killed as she walked across Cator Park. Her body was found  hours later close on Saturday evening close to the OneSpace community centre. The year one primary school teacher had been minutes away from meeting a friend at a pub when she was killed at around :pm. Her flatmate, who did not want to be named, had seen her earlier that day, saying: “I never thought something like this could happen to her.  She told“I had been texting her and it’s not like her to not reply to my messages. I don’t feel safe living here now.” The politan Police said a man was arrested in Lewisham, south east London. The force also released CCTV images of a man they wish to speak to and a vehicle they are searching for. This is the second arrest the politan Police has made in connection with the attack. On Saturday, detectives arrested a man in his s on suspicion of murder, who was then released under further investigation. The images of the man, taken from CCTV, shows him walking in Pegler Square on the evening Sabina was attacked. Police have also released an image of a silver vehicle they believe the man has access to, which was also captured in the Pegler Square area. They are urging anyone who recognises the man and vehicle to make contact immediately. title: sabina nessa how men can
story: :root Sabina Nessa: How men can help women feel safer while walking alone at nightThe murder of Sabina Nessa, six months after the death of Sarah Everard, has once again thrown the topic of womens safety walking the streets of UK towns to the forefront of conversation Image: REUTERSByAndrea Oldereide:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep  In the course of less than a month, two high-profile cases of women being murdered have sparked debates on how society can better womenaposs safety – the recent murder of American YouTuber Gabby Petito and of British school teacher Sabina Nessa. Femicide, the killing of a girl or woman, is a topic that has already been highlighted earlier this year, when Sarah Everard, a -year-old marketing executive, was killed in South London, on her walk back home. These victims tragically add to a horrying statistic that has been recently reported: six women are killed every hour by men around the world, according to UN data. Additionally, a woman is killed by a man every three days in the UK. According to Karen Ingala Smith, co-founder of the Femicide Census, men’s violence against women is a leading cause of the premature death for women globally but research in the UK and Europe is limited and unconnected. Dr Nilufar Ahmed who works as a Behavioural Psychologist at the University of Bristol helped us identy things men can do to help women feel safer and ways to stop violence towards women. How men can help feel women feel safer while walking alone  Being taught consent from a young age Men should learn to accept a womanaposs lack of interest in them. Violence inflicted on women is often entangled with sexual assaults, and therefore should be educated on consent. According to the United Nations Women , freely given and enthusiastic consent should be mandatory, “every time”. UN Women added that phrases like “she was asking for it” or “boys will be boys” attempt to blur the lines around sexual consent, placing blame on victims, and “excusing perpetrators from the crimes they have committed”.  Dr Nilufar Ahmed explained to the Mirror that changing our social attitudes was something that needed to happen across society and from an early age. She said: Understanding consent from an early age. ‘No means no’ is often framed in terms of sexual consent and rape, but it has a much bigger application –someone is rejecting your attention, friendship, or company in any setting, respect this. Schools can play a role in this by teaching young children about respecting boundaries. Being taught gender equality in schools The World Health Organisationpublished a pamphlet revealing that gender inequalities increase the risk of violence by men against women and inhibit the ability of those affected to seek protection. Experts have found that exposing children to non-stereotypical characters found in books and movies, as well as iding housework equally at home, can help children understand the notion that all genders are equal. Stop victim blaming Victim blaming is a way for someone to justy their motivation behind their own crime, while literally blaming their victim for their own action. Too often the behaviour and personalities of the women is scrutinised and judged first before the actions of the man who attacked them. Dr Nilufar Ahmed told The Mirror. She added: As though it is inevitable that a lone woman walking in the dark is automatically at risk of being attacked.  This victim blaming exonerates men from responsibility and blame by focusing on the woman. Allied with this, often when men commit heinous crimes, their crimes are qualied with added information about their lives as ‘good fathers’ or ‘high achieving students’, whilst the women are described only in terms of the way they were dressed and their actions that night. Becoming a better ally to women Doing something as simple as listening to women and their experiences goes a long way. Men should be able to acknowledge their privilege, as well as taking women’s concerns as a serious issue. Furthermore, men should not shy away from calling out blatant sexism and misogynistic behaviour when they witness it. Being supportive and contributing to the safety of women starts by becoming an ally. Destigmatise men’s mental health As the WHO found that potential perpetrators may be at an increased risk of committing femicidethey are unemployed, own a firearm, have made previous threats to kill with a weapon, or have committed sexual violence, men’s mental health needs to be addressed. Saying things like “man up” or “boys don’t cry” nourishes a culture of toxic masculinity which both prevents men from expressing their feelings, but also lead to dangerous behaviour such as resulting in violence instead of communication. According to Dr Nilufar Ahmed, there is not one reason that pushes men to harm and kill women, but it can include psychological reasons such as feeling rejected, feeling incapable of attracting a partner, being angry, feeling emasculated, a need to assert control, feeling entitled. These do not necessarily have to be about women – a man may experience repeated rejection from jobs, be angry at their landlord, etc, She said. She continued: Unaddressed, this can boil over and be projected onto a target that men are stronger than – women. Most men experiencing these will not go on to harm women butthese feelings are overwhelming go unresolved they can be damaging to the inidual and others around them, and could in extreme circumstances lead to aggression and even murder. If men are struggling with any of these issues accessing mental health support can help to work through them. Facilitate women’s access to protection and safety against domestic violence The WHO has revealed that there is an increased risk of perpetuating femicidethe aggressor has a history of intimate partner or family violence. A men with a history of domestic violence thereby is more likely to murder his partner. Domestic violence is reportedly not taken seriously in UK courts, as criminologist Jane Monkton-Smith toldthat her examination of  domestic abuse killings shows how sentences for manslaughter convictions were often mitigated by “ridiculous claims, like how much the perpetrator said they loved the victim”. Immediate things men can do to help according to a psychologist Dr Nilufar Ahmed said: Immediate things men can do are to be mindful to keep a safe distance from women when out walking or running. If you see a situation where a woman looks uncomfortable don’t be afraid to intervene either yourself or by making someone  aware .As a society we must all take responsibility for collective behaviours and actions. This means calling out comments and behaviour that are disrespectful to women whenever we encounter them. news uk-news sabina-nessa-six-unanswered-questions-"Sabina Nessa vigil: Crowds gather in Kidbrooke to pay tributeByTalia ShadwellReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep The public is being urged to share CCTV images of a mystery man and a silver car in hopes of bringing schoolteacher Sabina Nessaaposs killer to justice. Scotland Yard is appealing for help as detectives work around the clock to solve the -year-oldaposs murder in south London. Sabinaaposs death has led to widespread grief and amplied concerns about womenaposs safety after she was killed as she was about to set out on what should have been a five-minute walk. Sabina had left her Kidbrooke home to make the short journey across a park to a pub to meet a date at around .pm Friday when she vanished. A dog walker discovered her body under a pile of leaves at a park the following day. Sabina was described as “beautul, talented and caring” by her grieving sister. Pals said the talented young woman had dreams of moving abroad to teach in Dubai.  Where did she vanish  Detectives say Sabina, a teacher at the Rushey Green Primary School in Lewisham, set out on what would have been a five-minute journey to meet a friend at a pub in Kidbrooke Village, south London, at around .pm Friday. Her short journey would have taken her about  minutes from her Astell Rd home across Cator Park to get to The Depot in Pegler Square. Pals have said she was excited about going on a date with an old friend that evening at the bar. But she never arrived. Sabina was not reported missing by anyone after failing to show up to the bar. Adog walker found her body near a walkway close to the OneSpace community centre in Cator Park, Kidbrooke, in the Royal Borough of Greenwich at around .pm Saturday, under a pile of leaves. Police have not yet said publicly at what point of the journey she is believed to have been attacked.  What was the cause of death  A post-mortem carried out at Greenwich Mortuary proved to be inconclusive, police said on Monday. Detectives have said they believe she was hit with a heavy object and was taken to Cator Park, where her body was found. A Met Police spokesman said the force is not commenting on the reporting on the suspected murder weapon.Who killed her Police have said they were keeping an open mind on a motive to the killing, which has been widely reported as a suspected stranger attack Speaking at the scene where tributes had been laid to Sabina next to the police cordon at Cator Park on Thursday, Detective Chief Superintendent Trevor Lawry said earlier he is “keeping a completely open mind” on what the motive of the attacker may have been.  Asked whether detectives were worried the killer could attack someone , he said: “We have lines of inquiry that we’re pursuing at the moment. “It’s always a concern that it may happen, but that’s not something that we have any intelligence on at this time.” Asked whether he believed the killing was a stranger attack, DCI Lawry told reporters:“That’s definitely a line of inquiry that we’re looking at.” Sabinaaposs flatmate, speaking on condition of anonymity, told reporters she feels unsafe after losing her friend. Her fearful housemate of four months said she had last seen Sabina when the pair hung out and took pictures together.She told: ‘I never thought something like this could happen to her. I had been texting her and it’s not like her to not reply to my messages.“I don’t feel safe living here now.”  Who is the man in the CCTV images  Police say CCTV images of a man seen walking through south London is another person they would like to speak to. The force says the unknown man was in the area at the time of the attack, as well as pictures of a silver car they believe he has access to. The images of the man, taken from CCTV, shows him walking in Pegler Square, south London, on the evening Sabina was attacked. Where is the mystery car captured on CCTV going  Police have also released an image of the car they believe the man has access to, which was also captured in the Pegler Square area. Police are urging anyone who recognises the man and vehicle to make contact immediately. They have not revealed any more detail yet about exactly where or when the car was seen or what direction it was heading. However they have said they are appealing for sightings of the man and car across the south London borough of Greenwich, including in Catford, Kidbrooke and Greenwich itself. Have arrests been made  A man in his s was arrested on suspicion of murder at an address in Lewisham on Saturday evening, and was later released under police investigation. The politan Police announced on Thursday that a second, -year-old man had been arrested at an address in Lewisham on suspicion of Sabinaaposs murder and was being held in custody.  What you can you to help Police want to speak to anyone who may have seen anything that could help their investigation. Anyone who recognises the man in the CCTV images or has seen him in recent days is being urged to contact the Met. Detective Chief Inspector Neil John, from the Metaposs Specialist Crime Command, said: Our team have been working tirelessly to find the person responsible for Sabinaaposs murder and this has included an extensive trawl of CCTV, work which remains ongoing. We would ask anyone - especially those in Kidbrooke and the wider area of Lewisham and Greenwich - to take a careful look at these images to check whether you know who this man is or have seen him over recent days. Any information as to his identity or whereabouts could be vital for our investigation so we are asking you to share this image far and wide to ensure as many people as possible see it.  Where to attend the vigil for Sabina Nessa Vigils are being held for Sabina in locations around London later on Friday, and people are being encouraged to light candles on their doorsteps. Reclaim the Streets, a campaign group calling for an end to male violence against women, involved in organising previous vigils, said it is “angry and heartbroken” about her murder. Sabinaaposs death comes after the killings of Sarah Everard, who was knidnapped and murdered by a Met cop as she walked home, and sisters Bibaa Henry, Nicole Smallman, who were stabbed to death in a park. ‘I don’t feel safe living here now.’ Sabinaaposs community of Kidbrooke in Greenwich have organised a vigil at pm on Friday evening in Pegler Square, with the support of Reclaim these Streets. The vigil will be held to remember Sabina, how she lived and the lives she transformed as campaigners demand womenaposs rights to safety, the campaign group says. story: :root Simple staircase test can tell how much youre at risk of deadly heart diseaseHeart disease is one of the UKs deadliest killers as the British Heart Foundation say heart and circulatory diseases cause a quarter of all deaths in the countryExperts say to do a stair test to seeyou are at risk of heart disease Image: Getty Images MaskotByJames RodgerRegional Content EditorAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Sep | commentsHealth experts are urging people to do a simple stair test to seethey are at risk of heart disease.It has been suggested one of the UKaposs deadliest killers can be detected by walking up the stairs, BirminghamLive reports.Heart and circulatory diseases cause a quarter of all deaths in the UK, thataposs more than , deaths each year – or one death every three minutes, according to the British Heart Foundation. To perform the test, try and walk up four flights of stairs. If you are able to trek up the flights without trouble, youaposre not a risk, a study says.  Experts and researchers from the University Hospital A Coruna in Spain believe those who can manage the feat in less than a minute have better heart . Lead author Dr Jesus Peteiro, a cardiologist at University Hospital A Coruna, Spain, said: The stairs test is an easy way to check your heart health. If it takes you more than one-and-a-half minutes to ascend four flights of stairs, your health is suboptimal, and it would be a good idea to consult a doctor.  The main symptoms of coronary heart disease are: chest pain, shortness of breath and pain throughout the body, as well as feeling faint and also feeling sick . Last week, it was revealed in a study during a follow-up of almost  years of adults with hearts disease that continued low physical activity was linked to  per cent lower risk of dying from any cause. And sustained high physical activity was linked to a  per cent lower risk of death compared to those who are inactive, the Nord-Trondelag Health Study found.Coronary heart diseaseis a major cause of death in the UK and worldwide. CHD is sometimes called ischaemic heart disease or coronary artery disease. The main symptoms of coronary heart disease are:chest painshortness of breath pain throughout the body feeling faint feeling sick Coronary heart disease can develop when your heartaposs blood supply is blocked or interrupted by a build-up of fatty substances in the coronary arteries. The process - atherosclerosis - is when the walls of your arteries can become furred up with fatty deposits, which are called atheroma. Atherosclerosis can be caused by lestyle factors, such as smoking and regularly drinking excessive amounts of alcohol. Source: NHS There are about .million people living with heart and circulatory diseases in the UK, according to the British Heart Foundation. title: texting deceased loved one softens
story: :root Texting a deceased loved one "softens the harsh reality" says psychologistWhile before it may have been listening to an old answer phone message, now this modern coping mechanism is a new comfort for the bereavedHave you ever sent a text to a deceased loved one  Image: GettyByEmily Sleight:,  Sep | commentsLosing someone close to us can be extremely dficult - and many of us have dferent ways of coping with the grief. It’s important to note that everyone copes with grief in dferent ways, and there is no real right or wrong in the grieving process.With digital reminders of your loved one on social media s like Facebook and Instagram, things can get really tough. Although there are ways to turn off the profiles, you may still miss their online presence and knowing that they are a short message away for a quick chat.Reopening old text messages are bound to bring up many emotions, but what about those who continue to text their loved one  It’s now a common coping mechanism, and experts say it can actually be useful for those to deal with the transition. When considering why many people do this to cope with their loss, psychologist Ingrid Collins said: “When a loved one dies, we find it hard to adjust immediately to the fact that they are no longer physically with us. “In the first stages of grief, we tend to become emotionally numb as a result of the trauma of bereavement, often finding it dficult to accept that they are really gone.”FRisk is a wakeup call for the millions of people with no will or protection in place for their own death. FRisk is a FREE intuitive app that produces a FRisk Score confirming the level of risk your family and loved ones face were you to die without effective planning in place. Use Frisk to find out your own personal FRisk Score including: What would happen to your children  Who’s entitled to your estate  Who can bring claims  How much tax would you pay  What about your pets and your digital estate  Plus much more. Get your FREE FRisk Score now by clicking here. It is in this phase that many find it comforting to ease adjustment to a loss by continuing on a conversation. Ingrid continued: “Be it imaginary, as some believe, or communicating with the lingering soul of the loved one, as others believe. “Either way, it is a way of softening the harsh reality of never being in their physical presence again.  As a culture, it’s no doubt that we are taught to cope well with bereavement, with a “stf upper lip” approach for many. To some, that may signy that the inidual may not be coping well at all, and bottling up any emotions from others. When talking about text messaging loved ones that have passed away, Ingrid said: “Any method that enables us to prolong the comfort of the relationship with the deceased or,the bond was challenging, to go some way to resolving the relationship, is to be welcomed. “Sometimes people cling on to their loved one’s physical possessions that serve as a reminder. “This is one way of adjusting. Some take up a campaign in order to bring some meaning to what might otherwise appear to be a random or supposedly preventable death.” In short, those who choose to communicate with a deceased person are “taking an effective shortcut to arriving at some measure of acceptance.” Comment MORE ON GrievingText messagesFrisk" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. The pair were spotted dumping rubbish at a former LG site in Newport, South Wales, in September and October last year. story: :root UK weather forecast: Britain to sizzle in glorious C mini heatwave this weekendThe Met Office predicts that temperatures up to C could be experienced on Saturday as Brits are set to enjoy a sizzling weekend before the weather then cools down from MondayThe UK will see high temperatures up to C this weekend - meaning many will flock to beachesByDouglas Patient:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsThe UK will see high temperatures up to C this weekend with an Indian summer predicted for the next two days.The Met Office has said London and the South East could see maximum temperatures of C on Saturday, with both days having bright and sunny spells.Some pockets of England, just north of London, could also see highs of C or C. Sunday will be slightly cloudier but the temperature will otherwise remain around C in most places. The western parts of England and the whole of Wales could see some cloud and potential rain on Saturday morning before it brightens up in the afternoon with highs of C.  This could take a turn on Sunday with some heavy showers in the South East. North-western Scotland meanwhile will be windy in the morning on Saturday before becoming a mainly dry day with some bright or sunny spells developing and highs of C. Sunday will be largely dry and bright with strong southerly winds around the coast. The weather will take a turn on Monday, with the Met Office predicting next week to be the start of autumnal weather.It comes as people have been warned by the AA to not top up their cars outside of their normal routines ahead of planning any potential weekend trips away to take advantage of the weather. Nicky Maxey, for the Met Office, said: Youaposre much more likely to see highs of  degrees more widely but we could see some spots reaching highs of  or C.  It will be similar on Sunday, with places such as Lincolnshire potentially seeing similar temperatures, but still the higher temperatures being in isolated pockets rather than widespread. She added: Sunday perhaps will see an increased chance of rain, but thereaposs still plenty of sunny spells around and fine weather. But we have got a cold front moving in to Northern Ireland and Scotland on Sunday and then crossing from east to west of the UK on Monday. Thataposs bringing some potentially heavy rain. Thereaposs still some sunshine scattered round on Monday but we could see heavier showers. Hail and thunder is also a risk to the North and West, so Monday heralds a real change towards the autumnal-style weather. Weather forecast for Saturday: Starting rather cloudy with occasional drizzle or rain in the west, especially northwestern Scotland where it will also become increasingly windy. Some sunny intervals likely where. Very warm in sunshine. Outlook for Sunday to Tuesday: Still warm for many on Sunday, some heavy showers in the South East. news uk-news uk-weather-forecast-exact-date-"UK weather: Warm weekend with lots of cloud expectedByChiara Fiorillo:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsBrits have been enjoying warm temperatures this week, with the mercury reaching highs of C in southern parts of the UK. There will be three more days of sunshine - Friday, Saturday and Sunday - before the weather turns cooler next week. The mini-heatwave has only affected southern parts of the country, while northern areas have experienced strong winds and heavy rain. The best conditions and high temperatures will be felt in the east and central parts of the UK over the next few days, according to the Met Office. Met Office meteorologist Alex Deakin said: “Plenty more sunshine across much of the country today.  “Much of southern Scotland and certainly most of England and Wales will have another fine day of September sunshine. “Temperatures are responding to that sunshine, heading up into the low twenties - C, maybe C across parts of the south east.” But the early autumn sunshine will only continue for a few more days before torrential rain and gales hit Britain and temperatures turn cooler. The Met Office said that at the beginning of next week Brits will see a sht in weather conditions.An active weather front will bring heavy rain and blustery winds as it pushes in from the west across the UK, forecasters said. Meteorologist Adam Thornhill said: For the rest of this week and for the weekend, we will continue to see low pressure systems bringing blustery weather to the north of the UK whereas further south the drier, warmer weather remains thanks to the influence of high pressure extending up from the Azores. However, a sht in the position of the jet stream brings a change in our weather next week, allowing a cold front associated with a low-pressure system in the North Atlantic to spread eastwards bringing wet and windy conditions across the whole country throughout Monday.  Behind the cold front, conditions will feel much more autumnal with a cooler feel and blustery showers for many. Next week, gusty winds will create a more autumnal feel across many areas of the country. title: we deserve certain minimum teacher
story: :root We all deserve a certain minimum - teacher reveals sad incident that opened her eyes to hygiene povertyBoots and charity The Hygiene Bank are working together to stop pupils going without the basics - heres how you can helpAdvertorialByLaura Tait:,  Sep Contending with fidgety, distracted children is standard practice for teachers. But it was the reason why one particular child couldn’t focus that changed everything for deputy head-teacher Rebekah Wilson.“A boy in my class didn’t seem his normal happy self and he couldn’t concentrate for scratching his stomach,” says -year-old Rebekah, known as Bex. “He told me he didn’t have a bed at home, and the cushion he shared with his brother to sleep on was infested with bed bugs.”This was the moment that Bex, who works at an inner city primary school in Leeds, realised the impact that hygiene could have on her pupils and their education. “Times are hard for some families who are having to choose what they can do without,” she says. “Hygiene items often get sacriced. We’re not talking luxuries here, just the absolute basics like toilet roll, shampoo, deodorant, shower gel and soap. “Going without these things affects kids’ self-esteem. Imagine what it’s likeyou can’t keep yourself clean or you don’t have clean clothes  It can really stop children learning, engaging and taking part at school and it can lead to bullying or them being singled out.” Happily there’s an organisation that’s helping to relieve the pressure. The Hygiene Bank, which stresses that being clean is a basic human right, collects new, unused, in-date personal care and household cleaning essentials and distributes them to families in need through schools like Bex’s and charities.  And Boots has been supporting The Hygiene Bank by hosting more than  banks in stores across the UK where customers can donate their own hygiene products. The retailer then donates four products for every kilogram that has been donated. Toothbrushes and toothpaste are two items Bex knows are particularly needed. “So many children are coming to school with tooth problems now,” she says. “Bad dental health can cause a lot of pain and distress and really affect children’s confidence.” But something as simple as shampoo or shower gel can also improve the wellbeing and happiness of those struggling to stay afloat. “I had a mum in tears the other day because we’d given her a hygiene package that included some shower gel. As little as a p bottle can make a dference. She said it felt like Christmas.” Another mum had just £ left for her weekly shopping. “She needed nappies, washing powder and washing up liquid. She didn’t know what to buy because she knew she couldn’t get it all.” Hygiene products provided through The Hygiene Bank across the UK help fill the gap. “We all deserve a certain minimum,” says Bex. “We need to ensure every family has access to these basics, and remove the stigma of asking for support, making sure that families are treated with respect.” Boots leads big donation drive Boots and charity The Hygiene Bank are working together to provide much-needed hygiene and personal care products to people living in poverty.  In the last year, Boots, which has more than  donation points in stores across the UK, has given more than , items – from toothpaste to shower gel, soap to shampoo – to hundreds of communities and charities across the UK. Boots donates hygiene products to The Hygiene Bank. And since it believes every child has the right to feel good when they go back to school, Boots has also worked with the charity to design educational resources for parents and teachers to help young people understand hygiene and hygiene poverty. In its ‘You donate  we donate’ initiative, Boots gives four products for every kilogram of items donated to The Hygiene Bank in Boots stores.You can donate at your local Boots donation point, through the boots e-voucher scheme, and directly to The Hygiene Bank. Products are distributed to those who need them via schools, charities, council services and voluntary organisations. Milford on Sea Boots Store Manager Charlotte Whiteside says: “We’re very grateful for anything that our kind-hearted customers donate – but essentials include shampoo, toothpaste and sanitary products.” Shampoo Deodorant Toilet roll Period products Toothpaste Toothbrush Soap Nappies

news uk-news why-stormed-good-morning-britain-"GMB: Richard Madeley criticises activist over M protestopinionByLiam Norton:,  Sep | comments On Wednesday I appeared on Good Morning Britain. It all got a bit heated.I was prepared to be called a hypocrite, a fascist and to be asked why I don’t go to China to be shot at . I’ve been managing quite well during the last few weeks to stay calm during the barrage of questions that have been coming my way. People have been quite rightly furious and upset by what we are doing and I accept that. What frustrated me on Wednesday was the refusal by the other people on the programme to accept the physical reality we are in. The reality that Sir David King means when he says, “What we do in the next three to four years will determine the future of humanity”. That’s the reason I’m on the telly sitting through that rage and anger. It is because I really care about the country I live in and all the people who live here. Do you agree with Insulate Britainaposs actions  Have your say in the comments below  What the GMB presenters are not ready to accept is that climate breakdown isn’t primarily about survival of polar bears and dolphins, as important as they are, but about the survival of our economy, our NHS and of the very fabric of our society. This means many people will suffer.  What Insulate Britainis asking for is to conserve our society. To do that at this time means having to make some tough decisions, we understand that. The comparisons to Churchill on the programme upset Richard Madeley. I wasn’t saying that IB were the same as Churchill, what I was saying was that there were some similarities. The people that didn’t want to oppose Hitler were seen as appeasing Hitler. Churchill understood that you either faced up to the reality now or you paid for it later. He had the support of just six MPs. That meant that  million people lost their lives. It was locked in. There is a similarity now. If we don’t move as rapidly as Sir David King says we should, the suffering of millions of people in the next few decades will be locked in, unstoppable. What was happening on GMB on Wednesday was appeasement. A refusal to accept the reality, while also turning their anger of that reality onto me. Well we feel angry too. Angry that our government has ignored our letters, petitions and protests for  years.Insulating our homes is our line in the sand and we will not let them cross it. It gives the best value for money in terms of CO emissions, will provide hundreds of thousands of meaningful jobs and will stop tens of thousands of our elderly from freezing to death each winter and means families can heat and eat. This isnapost aboutmy home is insulated or not. Itaposs not about whether Iaposm a hypocrite for calling for all homes to be insulated. Itaposs about how tackling the climate crisis will not only save our country from destruction, but also benefit millions of our citizens and bring them out of fuel poverty. Itaposs a win-win. What Richard and Susanna don’t seem to understand is thatthe government continues to ignore us, it will get much more heated. story: :root Woman, , followed, grabbed by men while walking home in London day and nightTalisker Cornford, , founder of womens safety group Urban Angels, said she is harassed by men while walking home in London several times a weekTalisker Cornford said she is harassed multiple times a week Image: MyLondon WSByRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Sep Updated:,  Sep | commentsA womenaposs safety campaigner said she faces harassment from men at least three times a week while walking home. Talisker Cornford, founder of group Urban Angels, described how she has been grabbed and followed at all times of day while alone in London.“Sometimes itaposs subtle, she told My London. And sometimes itaposs very explicit.“Iaposve had people try and stop and talk to me a lot or try grabbing my arm and talking to me. Just being very persistent. Day and night. People shouting things at you, following you, I feel like thereaposs too many examples.” The -year-old, who set up the initiative in March in the wake of the Sarah Everard case, has seen it quickly grow to a worldwide community. She started it with a friend while studying in Exeter and similar groups were quickly launched in Birmingham, Cardf, Portsmouth and Brighton.Have you been affected by this story  Let us know at webnews@mirror  Talisker is in the process of setting up groups across London and next week one goes live in Amsterdam. Plans are also in the works for a Toronto version of Urban Angels. The group is used for alerts, discussions about safety measures, and many cities now have walking schemes to pair up people walking in the same direction late at night. She was speaking in light of the murder of Sabina Nessa, who was found dead in Kidbrooke, south-east London, on Saturday morning.The -year-old school teacher had been walking a short distance to the pub from her home the night before when she was attacked. It comes as Transport for London said it has no plans for theof the Night Tube until next year after the Covid pandemic saw the service halted. The   train service operated on Fridays and Saturdays for the Victoria, Jubilee and most of the Piccadilly, Central and Northern lines.It means night buses, taxis or walking are often the only means of transport home after dark. “Itaposs not a good move. In terms of womenaposs safety and safety for non-binary people,” said Talisker of the decision to hold off on reintroducing the service.  “I really want the Night Tube back. Andy Lord, managing director of the London Underground, said: “We are playing, and will continue to play, our full role in London’s recovery from the pandemic. We are running as close to a full service as possible across all our services and the Tube continues to serve Central London with last trains leaving around : and starting again at :. Our extensive night bus network continues to operate. We are continuing to review our options for when we might be able to reintroduce the full Friday and Saturday Night Tube in a safe and viable way and are exploring the feasibility of reintroducing some services on one or two lines more quickly.” Talisker believes people might feel safer using the Night Tube rather than the night buses which still operate across London but can be a minefield. “One of the big things for safety that a lot of people always say is familiarity, she said. If you donapost know where you are, you’re instantly less safe, because you kind of donapost understand which routes you are taking, youaposre potentially going to be out for longer or later.” The campaigner went on to say Tubes are in areas more densely populated and often staffed.
